Package cz.syntea.xdef

Contains interfaces for processing of X-definitions and the factory for compilation of X-definitions and creation of some important objects used in X-definitions.

See: Description

    XDBNFGrammar
    Datetime in x-script.
    XDBNFRule
    BNF rule in x-script.
    XDBuilder
    Provides building of XDPool.

    Value of array of bytes in x-script.

    Interface used to connect ScriptProcessor to debugging tools.

    Constants used by X-definition builder.

    Constructs XDValue from an iterated object fro XDResultSet.

    Interface fro debug mode.

    Provides processing of given X-definition.
    XDDuration
    Duration in x-script.

    Exceptions in the x-script.
    XDInput
    XD input stream/report reader in x-script.

    Named value (pair of name and value) in x-script.

    XD output stream/report writer in x-script.

    Parsers of string values.

    Result of parsers in XScript.

    Provides the interface to object containing compiled code of set of X-definitions.

    Regular expression in x-script.

    Result of regular expression in x-script.

    Reports in script see Report.

    Iterator/Map used as context in create mode of X-definition in x-script.

    External service (JDBC, XQuery, database etc).
    XDStatement
    External service statements (database etc) in x-script.
    XDValue
    Provides the interface for usage of internal objects of x-script.
    XDValueID
    Constants of ID's of implemented types of values of script.
    XDXmlOutStream
    Interface for incremental writing XML data to a stream in script.
    XDXQueryExpr
    Datetime in x-script.

Package cz.syntea.xdef Description

Contains interfaces for processing of X-definitions and the factory for compilation of X-definitions and creation of some important objects used in X-definitions.

For any kind of usage it is necessary first to compile X-definition to the objectXDPool. The XDPool object is fully reentrant (so that it can be declared as static and it can be used by many threads). XDPool contains compiled code generated form of all X-definitions. To compile X-definitions use the XDFactory - see static methods. To execute a X-definition you must first create an object XDDocument. This object contains pointer to the root X-definition where processing will start and it contains also all instances of objects needed for processing (variables etc). This object can be used for validation processing and/or for construction of XML data. In the multi-thread environment you must create this object for each thread.

There are several typical modes of usage of X-definition tools:

  • The most frequented mode is the "parsing" mode. In this mode the processor validates and processes input data represented from the input XML document. The important property of this mode is the ability to process XML files of unlimited size. If it is used the option "forget" in X-definitions the size of input data may be many gigabytes and it is not limited by the size of internal memory of the Java virtual machine. The speed of processor is typically over 1 megabyte per second. The method which provides this mode is XDDocument.xparse(java.io.File, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter).
  • Similar way of processing is the mode, where the XML document is available to the processor in the form of object of the org.w3c.dom.Document or org.w3c.dom.Element type. The input data are processed by recursive walking in the DOM tree. The size of the input data is of course in this case limited by the available memory. The method which provides this mode is XDDocument.xparse(org.w3c.dom.Node, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter).
  • The construction mode is designed to construct XML documents according to X-definition. In this mode the source data is generated by the X-definition itself (i.e. XDPool): the date can be taken from XML object or from external database or the external methods. The output data are created according to given X-definition (see XDDocument.xcreate(String, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter) or XDDocument.xcreate(javax.xml.namespace.QName, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter).

In the case you want to know properties of X-definition models of processed objects you can use methods: XXNode.getXMDefinition()
XXNode.getXMElement()
XXData.getXMData()
Those methods return an object with properties of processed data. The interfaces of such objects see package cz.syntea.xm.

  • XDPool

    Contains pool of X-definitions compiled from the source (see XDFactory).

    Example:

    
 //Prepare X-definition file
File xdef = new File("./src/Example.xdef");

// 1. Create DefPool and XDDocument.
XDPool xpool = XDFactory.genXDPool(null, xdef); //creation of XDPool
XDDocument xdoc = xp.createXDDocument(name); //create of XDDocument
  ...

  • XDDocument

    Validates XML source data (see XDDocument.xparse(java.io.File, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter)).

    Example:

    

// 2. Validate and process source XML data with X-definition.
ArrayReporter reporter = new ArrayReporter(); // here will be written errors
Element el = xd.xparse(sourceXml, reporter); //validate and process data
//now we have root element of parsed source data errors in variable el
//and list of errors in reporter
// 3. test if an error was reported
if (xd.errorWarnings()) {//error or warning reported?
        reporter.getReportReader().printReports(System.err);
} else {//no errors
        ....
}
  • Generates XML data from source data (see XDDocument.xcreate(String, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter) or XDDocument.xcreate(javax.xml.namespace.QName, cz.syntea.xdef.sys.ReportWriter) and XDValue.getElement()).

    Example:

    
//Set to ChkDocument parsed source element.
xdoc.setSourceContext(sourcedata); //element with source data

//construct XML document
ArrayReporter reporter = new ArrayReporter();
Element el = xdoc.xcreate("element namespace URI", "element name", reporter);
Element element = chkDoc.getElement();

/test errors
if (xdoc.errorWarnings()) {
        reporter.printReports(System.err); // print error messages
} else {
        System.out.println(KXmlUtils.nodeToString(element, true)); //print result
}

  • GenXDefinition

    You can create the X-definition from a XML document when you call the class GenXDefinition from command line: see: GenXDefinition.main(String[]).
